topic.title: Ham radio operators
topic.body: Are there any ham radio operators here?Or freebanders,anything :D

topic.title: Speedtest on Zer0Net
topic.body:
Hi guys,I was thinking about how could we measure speed on Zeronet.First I tried the javascript method using a picture file,but that doesn't worked as all files are being downloaded only once(and the script gives error on zeronet also)
It would be great to know how much bandwidth can we get from zeronet.As many users have broadband internet (I have 500mbps also) it would be fun to test download speed on site hosted by 100peers for example.
Any ideas how could we do this?

topic.title: How to autostart zeronet on linux without opening a browser window?
topic.body: Zeronet runs perfectly when I start it from GUI,but I would like to launch it on startup without opening a new browser tab.

topic.title: Any viable Tor/I2P alternative for browsing clearnet?
topic.body:
Is there any viable alternative to these two for browsing clearnet with anonimity?
They do the job,but the biggest problem is speed.VPN only gives you false feeling,as the operator knows everything.
Let me explain what I'm thinking about:today many people have serios internet speeds,including myself and our whole family,gigabit @ home,240mbit @ grandparents,etc.It would be great,if we had a P2P network similar to Tor,but designed to operate with really high-speed.I know,this requires the users to give their bandwidth,but it should be okay to share 10-100mbit when you have so much left.
Also,it shouldn't be as much secured as Tor,for example you don't really do darkweb stuff on clearnet :D But for general purposes,like watching p0rn,politically incorrect stuff,or if somebody is just behind a strict controll(router,firewall) let him browse freely,and not like a snail.
So,anybody knows any projects like this?Also,do you guys feel the need for such a thing too?

topic.title: Don't you think we need a highspeed Tor alternative for browsing clearnet?
topic.body:
Tor is sometimes(well,too often) very slow,and makes clearnet browsing unenjoyable.
I was thinking about a solution,which clearly does not offer that much security(on clearnet you won't be dealing drugs or watching cp - no hidden services),but enough that you can browse clearnet with that much anonimity with improved speed.
As I know,no such thing exists till this day.There was HORNET,but it got cancelled.
So I'm thinking about a decentralized network(no servers of course),and a Tor or I2P like routing thru peers.But every peer should act like an exit node too by default,unless that person decides to turn it off manually.Of course with an information on port 80,what software you run,and why could such traffic come from your IP.
What do you think about such an idea?I don't have the programming knowledge to even try starting something,but I don't think it should be that hard to write if someone has a little knowledge about networking and writing.

topic.title: What are "local peers" in zeronet connections?
topic.body: It's telling me I have a couple of them on every zite,next to onion,connectable,etc peers.And I clearly don't have anyone on my lan.What is that?

topic.body: Also freeband pirates(CB,EC,etc) as we are on a free,decentralized platform ;)

topic.title: Don't you think tracker exchange should be enabled through the peers?
topic.body: Loved tracker exchange feature in qbittorrent(until they have cut it out..),and worked nice.I think it would make zeronet even more decentralized.

topic.title: Tracker list site for Zeronet
topic.body:
I made the following site: http://127.0.0.1:43110/1PzpXVd3ghveQUsiKn8JBStVexcywtQ97V/
Originally got here from the idea of implementing tracker exchange.It's not the same by far,but it works.
Let's have a discussion,let's build a community based tracker list!(that works even in the case of the defaults failing :D )

topic.title: IPV6 using custom addresses
topic.body:
So I got a full /64 subnet from my ISP.All of my devices receive V6 addresses with the last 4 blocks being random.
I want to have my custom last 4 blocks,like 2001: ... ::1 or :acab:acab:acab:acab :D you get the point.The only way I could do it is by setting a manual V6 address in windows,typing the first 4 blocks from what I currently have,and setting the other half whatever I want.
Is there any way to do it,other than full manual?Something like a script that gets the current V6 address,and sets a custom one automatically with the first half given?

I thinked about this also.
It would be much better to use DHT.If we could use that,than zeronet would be really unkillable.

As I understand it works just the same as Bittorrent,even using the same trackers.That's why DHT would be a better solution for decentralization.
"trackers": [
            "zero://boot3rdez4rzn36x.onion:15441", 
            "zero://boot.zeronet.io#f36ca555bee6ba216b14d10f38c16f7769ff064e0e37d887603548cc2e64191d:15441", 
            "udp://tracker.coppersurfer.tk:6969", 
            "udp://tracker.leechers-paradise.org:6969", 
            "udp://9.rarbg.com:2710", 
            "http://tracker.aletorrenty.pl:2710/announce", 
            "http://explodie.org:6969/announce", 
            "http://torrent.gresille.org/announce"
        ],

> [nofish](#comment_777_1J3rJ8ecnwH2EPYa6MrgZttBNc61ACFiCj): The problem is DHT does not works well on Tor (btw. it's also requires bootstrap node: torrent clients usually uses router.bittorrent.com:6881)

Well,lol.I didn't think about enough yet another time.Yup,Tor could be a problem.And I didn't even know that DHT requires a node also.
I think we (I mean whole Zeronet) need to find a way to make it really decentralized.Okay,the content is distributed,but you can still shut down the tracker so peers won't find each other...

Yeah,this gave me the idea back that,but I haven't heard about it since then.Good to hear it's dead...nevermind,maybe someone sometime in the future :) 
Tor got faster than it used to be,but it's still upon you luck if you get a route with really slow node(s),or you can get reasonable speed out of it.
I forgot to mention,that in a similar network all peers should work as an exit node,not just a couple of selected ones.Of corse with a default page running on port 80 that tells the world you run something like this,and you ain't the one that browses hairy men f*cking all day long :DDD

I will set up an exit node on my server.maybe also an I2P exit.
I still think tho that a dedicated network for this would be great.When everyone runs exit nodes by default,isps and governments can't do anything.maybe Tor should work like that...

1534344680_14UupgrdnT7Y8vMES7aqUFgD1fC5R.body:
@ssdifnskdjfnsdjk yes,it supports PeX.peer exchange is not really like "every peer acts like a tracker".It means every peer has a list of peers,and it is being exchanged between peers.Lol,probably used "peer" too much :D 
It is a really smart mechanism which works well,but for example in extreme conditions when there are a couple completely different groups of peers,it won't work because they don't know about each other.
Of course,my example is just a theory,and that will only happen if no trackers are online,DHT is not working,etc etc,and the only way to find new peers is via PeX(it is pretty unlikely that a situation like this happens :D )
Still,I think tracker exchange would be a nice feature too,just one more base that makes zeronet even more decentralized.

In fact,started with your idea,I made a tracker list that is dynamically updateable:
http://127.0.0.1:43110/1PzpXVd3ghveQUsiKn8JBStVexcywtQ97V/
I will start a new thread,and let's have a discussion about it,maybe the concept is useful :D

Edit:up to 46,wtf? :DDD What's even more interesting,is I got several "zero://" ones.As I understand,those should be regular peers somehow acting like trackers.Maybe some exchange was implemented in the latest revision?It all started after I updated this morning.

My /Config page is empty,except for the list file :D well yes,it looks like nofish added tracker exchange,and some built-in zeronet specific tracker also.Which is awesome!
Edit:look at /Stats page.Confirmed,we have tracker exchange :)

1588068851_14UupgrdnT7Y8vMES7aqUFgD1fC5R.body: @xenovich as far as I know,it's pretty standard for ISPs to give 64bit blocks for users(which is dynamic tho,so after every router restart you get a new block).If you have IPV6,check the IP at least 2 devices on your network.If the first half is the same,then you got a 64bit block as well,with which you can do whatever you want.
